isis.stitle: AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH, TWO CYLINDER RECIPROCATING TYPE - After 01/01/1993 (R-134a) - REMOVE AND INSTALL - SHAFT SEAL

note.para: The seal can be replaced without compressor removal; however, the system must be discharged.

svcprocinfo.para: The shaft seal assembly of the compressor is of a simplified design, yet tight sealing, long lasting and, when necessary, easily and quickly replaced.

The tendency to condemn a seal assembly because of very slight leakage is an error that is often committed. Few if any mechanical seal assemblies are 100% tight. The rubbing surfaces of the seal are separated by a very fine film of oil.

Oil carries refrigerant, and minute quantities which seep to the outside may be detected with ultra sensitive leak detectors, which are capable of sensing leakage totalling one ounce of refrigerant over a twenty year period. Such sensitivity serves a useful purpose in critical applications, but for leak testing compressor joints or seal, a leak detector should be calibrated to pick up those leaks which are in excess of one ounce per year. Since shaft seals depend upon oil for lubrication and sealing, it is quite natural to find oil in the shaft cavity.

Do not be too prone to condemn and replace a seal assembly until the seal has been given an opportunity to "run in" and until there is definite proof that replacement is really necessary. Refer to GROUP 16 - A/C THEORY AND SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for more detailed leak detection procedures.
If a refrigerant leak from the area behind the compressor clutch is verified with a refrigerant leak detector, replacement of the compressor shaft seal is recommended.

note.para: Up to a few drops of compressor oil may normally be found in the area under the front seal. Do not replace a seal based on the presence of small amounts of oil. Verify a leak with a refrigerant leak detector before replacement, then proceed as follows:

step1.para: Remove the compressor from the vehicle. Refer to COMPRESSOR.
Remove the clutch pulley assembly and the clutch field coil. Refer to CLUTCH.
Remove the shaft key and dust cover.
Remove the seal plate bolts and seal plate ( Figure 9).
Remove the seal retainer with a seal puller ( Figure 10).

note.para: If any tool other than a seal puller is used, be careful not to damage the shaft or the machined surface on the front of the crankcase.

step1.para: Discard the seal assembly, seal plate and O-ring.
Clean the shaft and seal cavity with a clean, lint-free cloth.
Dip the seal retainer in mineral oil.
Remove the carbon ring from the new seal retainer assembly and set aside.
With a seal installer tool, push the lubricated seal assembly onto the shaft ( Figure 11).

Place the carbon ring in the ring retainer so the lapped surface is facing outward. Be sure the notches in the outside edge of the carbon ring engage the dimpled ring lugs in the seal spring retainer.
Lubricate the new O-ring with mineral oil and place it in the groove of the seal plate.
Position the seal plate with uniform clearance around the shaft and install the six capscrews ( Figure 12).
Tighten the capscrews in the sequence shown in Figure 13 to 5 to 8 ft-lbs. (6.8 to 10.8 N·m) ( Figure 14).
Replace the dust cover and key.
